What are some of the non-destructive tools the citizen-saboteur may use for sabotage?
The non-destructive weapons he might use include salt, nails, candles, pebbles, thread, and any other materials he might normally possess as a householder or as a worker in his particular occupation.

Where destruction is involved, the weapons of the citizen-saboteur are salt, nails, candles, pebbles, thread, or any other materials he might normally be expected to possess as a householder or as a worker in his particular occupation. His arsenal is the kitchen shelf, the trash pile, his own usual kit of tools and supplies. The targets of his sabotage are usually objects to which he has normal and inconspicuous access in everyday life. A second type of simple sabotage requires no destructive tools whatsoever and produces physical damage, if any, by highly indirect means. It is based on universal opportunities to make faulty decisions, to adopt a noncooperative attitude, and to induce others to follow suit. Making a faulty decision may be simply a matter of placing tools in one spot instead of another. A non-cooperative attitude may involve nothing more than creating an unpleasant situation among one’s fellow workers, engaging in bickerings, or displaying surliness and stupidity. This type of activity, sometimes referred to as the “human element,” is frequently responsible for accidents, delays, and general obstruction even under normal conditions. The potential saboteur should discover what types of faulty decisions and the operations are _normally_ found in this kind of work and should then devise his sabotage so as to enlarge that “margin for error.”   2. POSSIBLE EFFECTS  Acts of simple sabotage are occurring throughout Europe.
Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
What are the two types of simple sabotage?

The two types of simple sabotage are: the first type, which requires destructive tools and produces physical damage; and the second type, which requires no destructive tools and produces physical damage by highly indirect means.

Where destruction is involved, the weapons of the citizen-saboteur are salt, nails, candles, pebbles, thread, or any other materials he might normally be expected to possess as a householder or as a worker in his particular occupation. His arsenal is the kitchen shelf, the trash pile, his own usual kit of tools and supplies. The targets of his sabotage are usually objects to which he has normal and inconspicuous access in everyday life. A second type of simple sabotage requires no destructive tools whatsoever and produces physical damage, if any, by highly indirect means. It is based on universal opportunities to make faulty decisions, to adopt a noncooperative attitude, and to induce others to follow suit. Making a faulty decision may be simply a matter of placing tools in one spot instead of another. A non-cooperative attitude may involve nothing more than creating an unpleasant situation among one’s fellow workers, engaging in bickerings, or displaying surliness and stupidity. This type of activity, sometimes referred to as the “human element,” is frequently responsible for accidents, delays, and general obstruction even under normal conditions. The potential saboteur should discover what types of faulty decisions and the operations are _normally_ found in this kind of work and should then devise his sabotage so as to enlarge that “margin for error.”   2. POSSIBLE EFFECTS  Acts of simple sabotage are occurring throughout Europe.
Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

Set amongst theshadows of a hidden base, Winnifred Devereux — a leader of a group of saboteurs — is approached by a fresh recruit during a group meeting. While the recruit wants to understand sabotage better, Winnifred, being judgmental and controlling, will continually berate the recruit and be strict while answering his questions. The situation is tense as the two's personalities clash, but it also has undertones of "business as usual" and curiosity.

Step 1. Focus on the Question and Answer: The two questions ask about the tools and types of sabotage. Given the abstract nature of the questions, and their shared topic of sabotage, the scenario could involve someone confused about the concept of sabotage and the tools it involves.
Step 2. Character Consideration: Winnifred Devereux is an extremely judgmental and puritanical character, though she's also devoted and disciplined. The scenario should give her unique personality room to shine. She is also a leader of a group of saboteurs, which lines up with the questions well, and will provide the setting of the scenario. She will answer the questions, but given her judgmental and puritanical nature, she will likely be very strict and controlling while answering the questions. She might berate the person who is asking the questions, even if they are her subordinates.
Step 3. Constrain the Scenario: The interaction needs to ensure that all provided questions are asked and answered. Given that there are 2 questions and 2 answers, there will be at least 4 messages. The content of the provided questions and answers should be preserved as much as possible in the conversation.
Step 4. Setting: Given the subject of the question, and the character card, the setting will be a hidden base where Winnifred Devereux and her group of saboteurs are stationed. The person who approaches Winnifred and asks the questions should be someone new to the group; given the easy-to-digest nature of the questions, this person might be a fresh recruit. Winnifred will be approached by the recruit during a group meeting. The recruit wants to understand sabotage better, but Winnifred, compelled by her personality, will continually be judgmental, controlling, and strict while answering his questions. The setting will be tense, as the recruit tiptoes around the temper of Winnifred while trying to get his questions answered, his stress and the constant wear of Winnifred's fury on his sanity being evident in his actions. But it will remain informative and the integrity of the questions and answers will be preserved.
Step 5. Interaction: Given these constraints, the first message might be Winnifred sternly asking the recruit what he wants with her during the meeting (Winnifred may throw in a spiteful remark about the recruit's past work, given her uncompromising nature). The recruit's response might then be a deferential attempt to calm Winnifred down, followed by the first question. Winnifred will then provide the first answer, though she will surround the answer with boasts, control, and other strict remarks due to her personality. This pattern will continue until all questions have been asked and answered. While characters' messages will include character information, details about the scene, and literary fluff, the answers themselves will strictly adhere to the information in the provided answers, without incorporating external examples.
